Tuesday, June 5, 2007























'Dr. Death' goes free
Frail and smiling broadly, assisted suicide advocate Jack Kevorkian left prison Friday morning after eight years. The retired pathologist, convicted of second-degree murder for helping a Michigan man take his own life, still believes people have the right to die. 
FULL STORY

•  Kevorkian's release stirs emotions, memories


























NANCY GRACE Airs on Headline PRIME, 8 p.m. ET
"Nancy Grace" is television's only justice-themed interview and debate show. Nancy Grace challenges guests
on the most controversial and high-profile legal issues of the day by drawing on her unique perspective
as a former violent crimes prosecutor and as a crime victim herself.  Send your questions and comments.





















U.S.: KKK beat, drowned teens
Prosecutors in the kidnapping and conspiracy trial of reputed Klansman James Ford Seale say they will prove he was involved in the deaths of two black teenagers in 1964.
FULL STORY






Paris Hilton checks into jail
Paris Hilton has reported to a Los Angeles County jail to begin a three-week stay for violating probation in an alcohol-related reckless driving case. The celebutante slipped by the paparazzi.
FULL STORY






Execution takes 2 hours, 10 tries
Death penalty opponents called on the state to halt executions after prison staff struggled to find suitable veins on a condemned man's arm to deliver the lethal chemicals.
FULL STORY






Scalia's daughter is on probation
The daughter of U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia was sentenced to 18 months of court supervision under a drunken-driving plea bargain. Other charges were dropped.
FULL STORY
